Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Elucidating the interactive effects of sensory response and signal function on the evolution of signal diversity
Award.AbstractNarration: A fundamental challenge of modern Zoology is to understand why, in some cases, large numbers of similar-appearing animal species have formed, and continue to coexist, in relatively limited geographical areas. This study will examine the role of communication in facilitating species boundaries in communities of Anolis lizards. Male Anolis lizards utilize a visual communication signal that consists of the display of a colorful throat fan called the dewlap. Each species has a different color and/or pattern on its dewlap that helps to maintain species diversity by allowing lizards to easily detect, recognize and mate with members of their own species, and avoid interbreeding and unnecessary competition with other similar species. The dewlap?s effectiveness depends strongly on light conditions in each habitat, and on the neural responses of the Anolis visual system. This study will focus on lizard communities on the islands of Jamaica, Hispaniola and Puerto Rico. It will employ techniques from physics, optical engineering, neuroscience, behavioral biology, anatomy, and computer modeling to learn how lizard visual systems detect and discriminate between the colors and patterns found on the dewlaps of different species, and how differences in habitat light influence these capabilities. This project includes a strong educational outreach component. High school, undergraduate and graduate students will actively participate in all aspects of the research and a special effort will be made to include groups underrepresented in sciences. Findings will be communicated to the public via popular articles, public presentations, and web-based modules that allow interested individuals to explore the interactions between the physical properties of light, visual physiology, and ecological conditions. By explaining the role of effective communication in the maintenance of reproductive boundaries between species, the project will provide information that is critical for conservation efforts aimed at preserving biological diversity through habitat preservation and reconstruction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Below we provide a short description and illustration of the major findings of this project. Animal signals exhibit an astonishing diversity of physical forms even among closely related species. In many cases the evolutionary forces that generate and maintain this diversity are poorly understood. The adaptive radiation of West Indian Anolis lizards is an ideal model for testing predictions about which factors are responsible for the evolution of diversity of signal design. Anoles communicate using a colorful, expandable throat-fan (dewlap) and repetitive motion of the head and body (head-bobs). These signals are commonly used during courtship and territorial interactions.

Habitat Light and Dewlap Spectral Properties

 We hypothesized that Anolis dewlap color simultaneously serves two important functions: eliciting attention (= detectability), and providing an unambiguous signal of species identity. Under this scenario, diversity in anoline dewlap color evolves because (1) different habitat light conditions occupied by different species favor different optimal colors for both functions and (2) the color of a dewlap must diverge in perceptual space from the colors of other dewlaps in the community in order to unambiguously signal species identity

As part of this grant we sampled 21 species of anoles, from three different communities, which were found in the Greater Antilles islands of Hispaniola, Jamaica and Puerto Rico. For each of the species we sampled the habitat light spectral properties, downwelling light and background conditions, for ca. 35 individuals.

We collected spectral data using portable spectroradiometers from Ocean Optics, including a USB 2000 and a JAZ.  We collected habitat light properties (i.e., radiance and irradiance measurements), dewlap spectral properties (i.e., reflection and transmission), and spectral properties of the lizard bodies. In addition we captured digital photographs of the expanded dewlaps of five to ten individuals per species to characterize coloration patterns.

Our findings support the prediction that dewlap color has evolved under selection to be different from the background coloration, as illustrated by the dewlaps of sympatric species from Puerto Rico.  Figure 1 illustrates the positions of the dewlaps and background in color space, from the perspective of an anole. The color dots each representing a different species are not clustered with the background (green dots) and are different from each other. These results are consistent across all islands and communities that sampled.

Pattern Discrimination

We developed a robust associative learning behavioral paradigm to ask question about color perception and pattern discrimination in anoles. In a nutshell, the lizards are trained to remove a circular lid (2.7 cm in diameter) in order to gain access to a food reward. Once training has been achieved, the target stimulus (i.e., rewarded stimulus) and a distracter stimulus (i.e., non-rewarded stimulus) of the same size and shape but different pattern are presented simultaneously and the ability of the individual to discriminate between the stimuli is measured.

For this behavioral experiment we used A. evermanni (figure 2).  A species from Puerto Rico, which is has shown to be capable of learning this behavioral paradigm task in a relatively short period of time. We found that anoles were able to discriminate between the simplest patterns that are more commonly exhibited by the dewlaps of different species. These findings support the potential function of dewlap pattern in species recognition.

Experimental validation of the detection model under natural conditions. We used a remote controlled apparatus to display "fake dewlaps" to wild lizards to test for adaptive divergence in dewlap brightness (i.e., perceived intensity) among populations in situ.

As part of this grant we generated a theoretical model that was used to evaluate the efficacy of the signals under different habitat conditions (see above section). By experimentally testing those predictions under natural conditions we brought the system in a full-cricle.  We found evidence of local adaptation in dewlap brightness consistent with the sensory drive hypothesis. Specifically, dewlaps that had the brightness characteristics of local lizards were more likely to be detected than those with the brightness characteristics of non-local lizards. Our findings indicate that simplified mathematical representations of visual environments may allow robust estimates of relative detectability or conspicuousness in natural habitats
